title: If Flash becomes a built-in summoner spell, like Recall
body:
What happens to the balance of the game?

Since we've pretty much ruled out removing it, how about just handing it out? Since almost every champion takes it (except for maybe half a dozen, all of which can do fine with it anyway).

Will another single summoner spell take over? Will it actually create diversity and choice? Would it ruin the game or improve it?

Thoughts?
_
(Keep in mind this can go on the PBE as an experiment to see how it actually plays out.)_

Some thoughts on Flash:

* We think overall the game's more interesting with a really long CD fast reposition available to all champions than it is without such a tool. Removing Flash doesn't make sense as a result.

* For most champions not taking Flash isn't a reasonable option, so there's some missed opportunity in terms of offering meaningful choices there.

* We don't believe that 3 summoner spells is an appropriate way to go, in terms of complexity increase and either power creep or power diffusion (having to remove power elsewhere to pay for the availability of the new spell if not just power creeping).

* We could make Flash mandatory. Main thing that accomplishes is that it limits the small number of champions for whom Flash is optional. It also limits our ability to potentially expand that pool of champions a bit in the future (e.g. finding ways to make Ghost appealing on a few more champions via an item based upgrade or something similar). Cost of doing so seems higher than the benefits (helping new players primarily) as a result.

Honestly, it just seems completely unreasonable that having one summoner spell be 99.8% used on everyone remain that way. Why not try to force everyone to have flash (because literally 99.8% of the time they are running it.) and allow one different summoner spell alongside it? It could allow non-flash summoners to have power put into them and solidify what type of activity your champion wants to do (teleport for map mobility, ghost for chasing, ignite for execution, exhaust for defence, etc). Simply because at this moment, its a noob trap on all but a very small group of champions to not take flash. Riot should do something about it, simply because of the momentous usage rate this spell has.

While I agree with your points on flash, are you looking at improving the other summoner spells in the near future? {{summoner:21}} {{summoner:1}} {{summoner:6}}

Power creep/diffusion and complexity makes sense. But since all champions get the extra summoner spell, every champion can pick _two_ summoners that best suit them and their playstyle.

It will probably mess with balance quite a bit, but every summoner other than Clairvoyance will likely significant use and this will probably significantly shake up the meta. You might be able to toss this out into the PBE and see what happens.

What would you say it is that makes a game with Flash more interesting than a game without it? I can understand that having anything with flexible use, a powerful effect, and a long cooldown can lead to some interesting use cases, but most of the time (even in LCS and Worlds), I mostly see it used as a gimme or a crutch. Accidentally stepped out of position or got caught out? _You've got Flash for that_. Enemy managed to get away from you with a sliver of health and you're not quite close enough to use your ult? _You've got Flash for that_. Dude you're ganking saw you coming but you still want to get that kill? _You've got Flash for that_. Didn't see the jungler coming after they took the time to coordinate with their ally but want to not die anyway? _You've got Flash for that_. Enemies on your ass and you aren't close enough to your tower to fend them off? _You've got Flash for that_. Overstayed your welcome under the enemy's tower and know that the shot after this one will kill you? _You've got Flash for that_, etc., etc., etc.

While there's no doubt that there's pockets of depth that Flash brings to the game that wouldn't be so universal if it didn't exist, it honestly feels like something that dumbs down the game as a whole - since for every cool and strategic use for it, there are hundreds of get-out-of-jail-free cards. The "big plays" involving Flash that Riot and the eSports community talk about are more often than not really, well, flashy displays of split-second reaction time (Thresh flashing through an Ashe ult and hooking her immediately, for example), rather than jaw-dropping moments of strategic and tactical finesse. There's nothing wrong with a little shock and awe, of course, but it feels a bit misaligned with the strategic depth that you guys are constantly seeking to add to and refine within League of Legends!

I guess in general, [I'm more inclined to agree with Zileas on this one](http://i.imgur.com/0VUMriu.png). Not to say that League isn't already fun with Flash as a mandatory summoner spell, or that the inclusion of Flash drastically reduces the possible variety of champion types and playstyles, but I do think that a game without Flash would lead to a playerbase that ultimately improves at the game at a faster pace (since lessons in the form of grey screens tend to be more effective than the slap on the wrist of having to wait a few minutes before you can safely screw up again), a game filled with greater and more impactful gameplay consequences (especially in professional play), and a competitive roster that isn't limited to, more or less, who can optimize this really, really powerful tool the most.

{{summoner:4}} Flash has it's uses, I can see that. However {{summoner:6}} Ghost allows for its own unique strategical mindgames and options due to its long duration mobility.

There's nothing more fun than popping {{summoner:6}} Ghost as {{champion:12}} Alistar and deftly dodging skillshots by running about as your opponents panic as you jog alongside them. Popping {{summoner:4}} Flash only to see you sprint back up to them for the Pulverise.

{{summoner:4}} Flash is about making a play quickly so that your opponent cannot react to you or to save you from a bad position. I personally prefer the slower, strategical approach {{summoner:6}} Ghost offers me that lets me work around my opponent's efforts to slow me down.
